Package eea.engine.action.basicactions

This package provides a set of default basic actions that modify objects.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
ChangeStateAction A ChangeStateAction is an action used to change the game state, e.g.
ChangeStateInitAction A ChangeStateInitAction is an action used to change the game to its initial state, e.g.
DestroyEntityAction A DestroyEntityAction is used to "destroy" and entity by removing it from the list of active entities in the StateBasedEntityManager.
MoveBackwardAction A MoveBackwardAction is an action used to model a backwards move of an entity.
MoveDownAction A MoveDownAction is an action used to model a downwards move of an entity.
MoveForwardAction A MoveForwardAction is an action used to model a forwards move of an entity.
MoveLeftAction A MoveLeftAction is an action used to model a move of an entity to the left.
Movement Movement models the movement of an entity based on the current speed
MoveRightAction A MoveLeftAction is an action used to model a move of an entity to the right.
MoveUpAction A MoveUpAction is an action used to model a upwards move of an entity.
QuitAction A QuitAction is a simple but important action that is used inform the game that the user has quit (finished/left) the game This is typically the case when the user has pressed a certain button or key, e.g.
RemoveEventAction The RemoveEventAction is a straightforward action that is used to remove the chosen event from the underlying entity.
RotateLeftAction A RotateLeftAction is an action used to model the rotation of an entity to the left, more precisely: in counter-clockwise direction.
RotateRightAction A RotateLeftAction is an action used to model the rotation of an entity to the left, more precisely: in clockwise direction.
SetEntityPositionAction SetEntityPositionAction models the explicit placement of an entity to a given spot.
 

Package eea.engine.action.basicactions Description

This package provides a set of default basic actions that modify objects. More precisely, the following basic actions are currently supported:

  • Changing to the initial state of the game, e.g., after the user has won or lost the game and or has pressed a "new game" button or key, using the ChangeStateInitAction class.
  • Destroying an entity and removing it from the game display, e.g., once the player has "shot, exploded or picked up" the given entity. This uses the DestroyEntityAction class.
  • Moving an object based on an associated user action or internal trigger (the latter is typically the case for computer-steered entities).
    The movement occurs in six possible ways: up, down, left, or right, all of which only modify either the x or y position of the entity - but not both - and ignore its current orientation, or forward / backwards, which modify both x and y position based on the current orientation of the entity. In all cases, the movement speed and the time passed are taken into account.
    Each movement operation is implemented in a separate subclass of Movement, e.g. MoveDownAction.
  • The QuitAction is used to tell the game engine that the user has quit the game (voluntarily or otherwise).
  • If an entity shall no longer be informed of a certain event, use RemoveEventAction.
  • Rotations are modelled using the pair of RotateLeftAction and RotateRightAction classes, depending on whether the direction is in clockwise ("right") or counterclockwise ("left") orientation.
  • "Teleport" effects, where an entity directly assumes a fixed position, are modelled using the SetEntityPositionAction class. This can for example be used by objects that leave the game area at one border and shall then reappar up at the opposite border. (Old gamers may think of the "tunnels" in Pac-Man).
